entry.et: Middle English raye, from Anglo-French raie, from Latin raia

def.dt: :any of an order (Rajiformes) of usually marine cartilaginous fishes (as stingrays and skates) having the body flattened dorsoventrally, the eyes on the upper surface, and enlarged pectoral fins fused with the head

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French rai, from Latin radius rod, ray

def.dt: :any of the lines of light that appear to radiate from a bright object
:a beam of radiant energy (as light) of small cross section
:a stream of material particles traveling in the same line (as in radioactive phenomena)
:a single particle of such a stream
:light cast by rays :radiance
:a moral or intellectual light
:a thin line suggesting a ray: as
:any of a group of lines diverging from a common center
:half line
:one of the bony rods that extend and support the membrane in the fin of a fish
:one of the radiating divisions of the body of a radiate animal (as a starfish)
:a branch or flower stalk of an umbel
:medullary ray
:vascular ray
:ray flower 1
:particle trace a ray of hope
:to shine in or as if in rays
:to issue as rays
:to extend like the radii of a circle :radiate
:to emit in rays
:to furnish or mark with rays
John 1627–1705 Eng. naturalist
Nicholas 1911–1979 born Raymond Nicholas Kienzle Am. film director
Satyajit 1921–1992 Indian film director, writer, & producer
:one of the marginal flowers of the head in a composite plant (as the aster) that also has disk flowers
:the entire head in a plant (as chicory) that lacks disk flowers
:a stingray (Myliobatis californica) of coastal waters from Oregon to the Gulf of California having two long pectoral fins and a large protruding head
:beta particle
:a stream of beta particles called also beta radiation
:the high-speed electrons emitted in a stream from the heated cathode of a vacuum tube
:a stream of electrons emitted from the cathode of a vacuum tube usually used in plural
